RAMBLINGS IN SCIENCE
By SYLVAN D. SOLARZ

DR. W. W. CORT, professor of helminthology
at the Hopkins, sailed for Egypt on March 20, to
make investigations on schistosomiasis and hookworm disease. Dr. Cort, who will return in July, is
to work under the auspices of the International
Health Division of the Rockefeller Institute.

Friday, March 23, 1934.

Interest And Profit
That old bugaboo of a gymnasium for the Hopkins has bobbed up again with the well-founded rumor being afoot that the authorities are casting out
their lines for bids at the present time. This development has many interesting possibilities.
It may or may not tie up with the recent protest
of the student body against athletic conditions at the
University, which protest was put into the hands of
the Board of Trustees last month and immediate action upon which is desired by all parties concerned.
Without wishing to detract one whit from the good
intentions of the Board, we confidently assert that
its attention would never have been directed to the
matter, had it not been for the tireless and unflinching
efforts of Norman Heaney and his associates in
framing the protest and in pushing it to such an extent
that the Board was compelled to take cognizance of
its moment.
This is by no means a'ssuming a "We did it, fellows" attitude, just because the NEWS-LETTER happened to be the cannon through which most of the
thunderous bombardment was carried on. Indeed,
the action of the Athletic Association in sending out
"feelers" may be prompted by quite different motives.
Yet the indisputable fact remains that student interest when properly crystallized and organized, as was
the case in this instance, can be employed as an
effective weapon of protest.
Definite announcement of the Board's decision as
to the entire situation will not be long forthcoming.
Regardless of the specific details of this decision,
however, the undergraduate body can take full pride
in the realization that it did its share of the work by
attentive attendance at the "open forum" assemblies
and by other such manifestations of wholehearted
support. Once the natural leaders had displayed
themselves, the rest of the army followed behind
resolutely and in step.

Quite Coincidental
While searching for a text which would permit
us to put aside our seemingly inherent faculty for
criticism and substitute in its stead an atmosphere of
blitheness, we came upon the subject of coincidences.
Bearing the dictionary interpretation of "two things
occurring at the same time," these phenomena have
always proved a source of painful interest to us ever
since that yesterday when we ate four green apples
at one tree-climbing and then had the doctor come to
our house for four consecutive days. We're still
seeking the significance of this coincidence, especially
in view of the fact that "an apple a day keeps the
doctor away." (Now that you have caught us in a
blithesome mood, perhaps you appreciate our serious
side all the more.)
The Hopkins has its full portion of coincidences.
For instance, consider the following which come
quickly to mind, together with their logical explanations:
Dr. David M. Robinson and party reached Greece
the very day that Samuel Insull attempted his unsuccessful disappearing act. Comment—Insull, no doubt,
realized he couldn't hide anywhere in Greece with any
degree of safety when the good doctor inaugurated
his digging exercises.
All of the less fertile minds apparently congregated in one of the three Elements of Economics sections, judging from the fact that a total of one (1)
Honor was duly granted to a class consisting of approximately seventy-five students. Comment—And
we thought that Christmas was a long way off!
When the NEWS-LETTER recently condemned the
Athletic Association for an obvious lack of proper
equipment, the latter group remembered that it had
just Ordered some new uniforms. Comment—Those
boys certainly can keep a secret!
Feminine members of the College for Teachers
have been observed of late reading cinema magazines
rather than their scholarly texts. Comment—Doubtless the photographers of the city papers have put
ideas into their heads. Is there no way of discouraging them? Just think of our poor children in the
public schools learning that Mae West is a national
figure and Greta Garbo a Swedish ambassador of
good-will!
When you read this, we'll be at Temple University attending the I. N. A. Convention. Comment
censored.

WE SEE that Dr. William Beebe has been awarded
funds to attempt to better his 2,200 feet record that
he set when he descended to that depth in his bathysphere off Bermuda in 1932. The money has been
set aside by the National Geographic Society.
As a result of Dr. Beebe's work, there has been
a great increase of the knowledge of the habitat actions of tropical fish. Now the time is ripe for some
up-and-coming song-writer to dash one off to the
effect of "Sitting in a Tub, Watching the Fish Stroll
By". (We pass the title on for what it is worth.)
0-0

THE archaeologists of the world have been
prompted to wide-spread comment by the report of
the discovery of the legendary city of the Queen of
Sheba, who is known in legendary history only by
her visit to King Solomon.
Discovered by Andre Malraux, French writer, the
city is vaguely located in the Great Arabian Desert,
about 900 miles nrotheast of Djibouti. Archaeologists
are waiting for definite evidence before they confirm
what will probably, if true, be 1934's biggest archaeological find.

INTERCOLLEGIATES
According to the Polytechnic Reporter, a professor at an Eastern college posted this bulletin: "If
the person who stole the alcohol from the laboratory
will kindly return the cat's intestines, no questions
will be asked."
It is reported that co-eds at Purdue are now offered a course in charm, designed to teach them how
to avoid spilling cocktails on evening dresses and how
to smoke gracefully—and other things, of course.
The University of Delaware reports the following
advertisement as having appeared in the college paper
of the University of British Columbia: "Wanted—A
Freshette, with a car, to 'escort male junior to frosh
reception."

SEC. 4. Unless the penalty is rendered
by the Tribunal at the time of the trial,
no more than two days shall elapse before the said penalty shall be rendered.
The penalty imposed by the Tribunal on
any fraternity or fraternities convicted
under Section 4 of this Article may include any one or several of the following:
(1). A fine of crom one dollar ($1.00)
to one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(2). Prohibition of pledging to a definite or indefinite date.
(3). Suspension from the Interfratertiity Board, followed .by a letter to
the national organization of said fraternity. This suspension shall include the
suspension of all rights and privileges
such as voting, rushing and pledging.
(4). Expulsion from the Interfraternity Board followed by a letter to the
national fraternity headquarters demanding that the Charter of the local Chapter
be revoked.
A man may be convicted apart from
his fraternity and if this occurs his fraternity shall be liable for his fine or penalty.
SEC. 5. Any member of the Board or
the Tribunal convicted under Section 4
of this Article shall automatically he expelled from that organization.

Radio Stars Head
Cigarette Program
Rosa Plonselle, world-famous soprano; Nino Martini, noted radio
tenor; and Grete Stueckgold, popular concert singer, will sing the
best-loved American songs in a new
series of broadcasts to be heard
three times weekly over the Columbia network, beginning Monday,
April 2.
Presented under the auspices of
Liggett & Myers Tobacco Company,
in behalf of Chesterfield Cigarettes,
the programs will be broadcast
from 9.00 to 9.30 p. m., E. S. T.,
every Monday, Wednesday and
Saturday.

Spiked Shoe Arranges
Extensive Intramural
Track And Field Meet

St. John's Admitted
To Maiyland League

BEELER

St. John's College was admitted
to the Maryland Collegiate Basketball League for the. 1934-35 season
at a meeting of the association early
this week.
The addition of St. John's to the
league increases the total number
of teams to six. Washington College, Loyola, Mount St. Mary's,
Hopkins and Western Maryland
are the other members of the
league.
St. John's applied for admission
this past season, but its application
came in too late to schedule the necessary games. For this reason the
request was not acted upon until
now.
At the conclusion of the meeting,
President Tom Kibler presented the
trophy emblematic of the team
championship to Dick Harlow, who
represented Western Maryland.
Neil Stahley, who coached the victorious Terrors this season is no
longer connected with Western
Maryland.
Mount Saint Mary's, winner of
the trophy last year, finished in a
tie for second place with Hopkins,
this year. The•trophy must be won
three times to be kept permanently
It was announced that games next
year will again be played on a home
and home basis. Each team will
list 10 opponents.

excellent test of intramural feeling

turnout that is expected materializes, it will denote that there is a

SWIMMERS
Blue Jay Tank Squad To
Enter South Atlantics As
Club Team
Although the swimming team has
disbanded for the season, several
members of the squad will participate in the South Atlantic Championship meet under the affiliation
of the Blue Jay club. Outstanding
for the Jays will be Eddie Sadtler,
Woody White, and Frank Levi.
The club will also be represented by
the relay team, which has been victorious for the last two years.
White, next year's captain, is coholder of the 100-yard title, while
Levi captured third place in this
event.
Because of A. A. U. rulings, Lou
Adler, Buddy Adler, and Danny
Weiner *ill. be unable to .represent
the; Blue jays.
The two ,Adler
brothers will enter the 220-yard
free style, while Weiner will compete in the 100-yard backstroke.
Lou Adler scored twice in 1933,
gaining a second in the furlong
swim and third in the 50-yard dash.

program over WCBM, a' regular
weekly feature, will not be broadcast tomorrow night.

By SYLVAN D. SOLARZ

DR. W. W. CORT, professor of helminthology
at the Hopkins, sailed for Egypt on March 20, to
make investigations on schistosomiasis and hookworm disease. Dr. Cort, who will return in July, is
to work under the auspices of the International
Health Division of the Rockefeller Institute.

Interest And Profit
That old bugaboo of a gymnasium for the Hopkins has bobbed up again with the well-founded rumor being afoot that the authorities are casting out
their lines for bids at the present time. This development has many interesting possibilities.
It may or may not tie up with the recent protest
of the student body against athletic conditions at the
University, which protest was put into the hands of
the Board of Trustees last month and immediate action upon which is desired by all parties concerned.
Without wishing to detract one whit from the good
intentions of the Board, we confidently assert that
its attention would never have been directed to the
matter, had it not been for the tireless and unflinching
efforts of Norman Heaney and his associates in
framing the protest and in pushing it to such an extent
that the Board was compelled to take cognizance of
its moment.
This is by no means a'ssuming a "We did it, fellows" attitude, just because the NEWS-LETTER happened to be the cannon through which most of the
thunderous bombardment was carried on. Indeed,
the action of the Athletic Association in sending out
"feelers" may be prompted by quite different motives.
Yet the indisputable fact remains that student interest when properly crystallized and organized, as was
the case in this instance, can be employed as an
effective weapon of protest.
Definite announcement of the Board's decision as
to the entire situation will not be long forthcoming.
Regardless of the specific details of this decision,
however, the undergraduate body can take full pride
in the realization that it did its share of the work by
attentive attendance at the "open forum" assemblies
and by other such manifestations of wholehearted
support. Once the natural leaders had displayed
themselves, the rest of the army followed behind
resolutely and in step.

Quite Coincidental
While searching for a text which would permit
us to put aside our seemingly inherent faculty for
criticism and substitute in its stead an atmosphere of
blitheness, we came upon the subject of coincidences.
Bearing the dictionary interpretation of "two things
occurring at the same time," these phenomena have
always proved a source of painful interest to us ever
since that yesterday when we ate four green apples
at one tree-climbing and then had the doctor come to
our house for four consecutive days. We're still
seeking the significance of this coincidence, especially
in view of the fact that "an apple a day keeps the
doctor away." (Now that you have caught us in a
blithesome mood, perhaps you appreciate our serious
side all the more.)
The Hopkins has its full portion of coincidences.
For instance, consider the following which come
quickly to mind, together with their logical explanations:
Dr. David M. Robinson and party reached Greece
the very day that Samuel Insull attempted his unsuccessful disappearing act. Comment—Insull, no doubt,
realized he couldn't hide anywhere in Greece with any
degree of safety when the good doctor inaugurated
his digging exercises.
All of the less fertile minds apparently congregated in one of the three Elements of Economics sections, judging from the fact that a total of one (1)
Honor was duly granted to a class consisting of approximately seventy-five students. Comment—And
we thought that Christmas was a long way off!
When the NEWS-LETTER recently condemned the
Athletic Association for an obvious lack of proper
equipment, the latter group remembered that it had
just Ordered some new uniforms. Comment—Those
boys certainly can keep a secret!
Feminine members of the College for Teachers
have been observed of late reading cinema magazines
rather than their scholarly texts. Comment—Doubtless the photographers of the city papers have put
ideas into their heads. Is there no way of discouraging them? Just think of our poor children in the
public schools learning that Mae West is a national
figure and Greta Garbo a Swedish ambassador of
good-will!
When you read this, we'll be at Temple University attending the I. N. A. Convention. Comment
censored.

WE SEE that Dr. William Beebe has been awarded
funds to attempt to better his 2,200 feet record that
he set when he descended to that depth in his bathysphere off Bermuda in 1932. The money has been
set aside by the National Geographic Society.
As a result of Dr. Beebe's work, there has been
a great increase of the knowledge of the habitat actions of tropical fish. Now the time is ripe for some
up-and-coming song-writer to dash one off to the
effect of "Sitting in a Tub, Watching the Fish Stroll
By". (We pass the title on for what it is worth.)
0-0

THE archaeologists of the world have been
prompted to wide-spread comment by the report of
the discovery of the legendary city of the Queen of
Sheba, who is known in legendary history only by
her visit to King Solomon.
Discovered by Andre Malraux, French writer, the
city is vaguely located in the Great Arabian Desert,
about 900 miles nrotheast of Djibouti. Archaeologists
are waiting for definite evidence before they confirm
what will probably, if true, be 1934's biggest archaeological find.

INTERCOLLEGIATES
According to the Polytechnic Reporter, a professor at an Eastern college posted this bulletin: "If
the person who stole the alcohol from the laboratory
will kindly return the cat's intestines, no questions
will be asked."
It is reported that co-eds at Purdue are now offered a course in charm, designed to teach them how
to avoid spilling cocktails on evening dresses and how
to smoke gracefully—and other things, of course.
The University of Delaware reports the following
advertisement as having appeared in the college paper
of the University of British Columbia: "Wanted—A
Freshette, with a car, to 'escort male junior to frosh
reception."

SEC. 4. Unless the penalty is rendered
by the Tribunal at the time of the trial,
no more than two days shall elapse before the said penalty shall be rendered.
The penalty imposed by the Tribunal on
any fraternity or fraternities convicted
under Section 4 of this Article may include any one or several of the following:
(1). A fine of crom one dollar ($1.00)
to one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(2). Prohibition of pledging to a definite or indefinite date.
(3). Suspension from the Interfratertiity Board, followed .by a letter to
the national organization of said fraternity. This suspension shall include the
suspension of all rights and privileges
such as voting, rushing and pledging.
(4). Expulsion from the Interfraternity Board followed by a letter to the
national fraternity headquarters demanding that the Charter of the local Chapter
be revoked.
A man may be convicted apart from
his fraternity and if this occurs his fraternity shall be liable for his fine or penalty.
SEC. 5. Any member of the Board or
the Tribunal convicted under Section 4
of this Article shall automatically he expelled from that organization.

Without vacuum tubes, Long Distance telephony would hardly be possible. But with these

mile intervals along the line—even a whisper carries
from coast to coast!
With many tubes used in tandem, individual performance must be almost perfect—or cumulative
distortion would render speech unintelligible. That
today's Long Distance connections are so reliable
and clear, is a tribute to the skill used in making
Western Electric tubes.

Western Electric contributes much to the quality
of telephone service.

Track And Field Meet

St. John's Admitted
To Maiyland League

BEELER

St. John's College was admitted
to the Maryland Collegiate Basketball League for the. 1934-35 season
at a meeting of the association early
this week.
The addition of St. John's to the
league increases the total number
of teams to six. Washington College, Loyola, Mount St. Mary's,
Hopkins and Western Maryland
are the other members of the
league.
St. John's applied for admission
this past season, but its application
came in too late to schedule the necessary games. For this reason the
request was not acted upon until
now.
At the conclusion of the meeting,
President Tom Kibler presented the
trophy emblematic of the team
championship to Dick Harlow, who
represented Western Maryland.
Neil Stahley, who coached the victorious Terrors this season is no
longer connected with Western
Maryland.
Mount Saint Mary's, winner of
the trophy last year, finished in a
tie for second place with Hopkins,
this year. The•trophy must be won
three times to be kept permanently
It was announced that games next
year will again be played on a home
and home basis. Each team will
list 10 opponents.

Prove Excellent Test
The meet should prove to be an
excellent test of intramural feeling
at the University, and if the large
turnout that is expected materializes, it will denote that there is a
demand for intramural sports here.
The track squad has been practicing daily under the tutelage of
Coach Hambleton in preparation
for an extensive campaign. A large
number of veterans, including King,
Holtzman, Clark, Lewis, Mercer,
Moravek, Coburn, Leberfeld, and
Weeks, help make prospects bright
for a successful season.

SWIMMERS
Blue Jay Tank Squad To
Enter South Atlantics As
Club Team
Although the swimming team has
disbanded for the season, several
members of the squad will participate in the South Atlantic Championship meet under the affiliation
of the Blue Jay club. Outstanding
for the Jays will be Eddie Sadtler,
Woody White, and Frank Levi.
The club will also be represented by
the relay team, which has been victorious for the last two years.
White, next year's captain, is coholder of the 100-yard title, while
Levi captured third place in this
event.
Because of A. A. U. rulings, Lou
Adler, Buddy Adler, and Danny
Weiner *ill. be unable to .represent
the; Blue jays.
The two ,Adler
brothers will enter the 220-yard
free style, while Weiner will compete in the 100-yard backstroke.
Lou Adler scored twice in 1933,
gaining a second in the furlong
swim and third in the 50-yard dash.

Due to the absence of Hyrnall
Levin from the city until next
Monday, the "Campus Comments
program over WCBM, a' regular
weekly feature, will not be broadcast tomorrow night.

Mounts Open Season
Mount Washington Country Club
will open its lacrosse campaign tomorrow when it tackles Swarthmore College at Mount Washington.
Prospects appear brighter for the
Wolfpack this year than in a long
time and the clubmen should therefore have no trouble in winning tomorrow. The addition of Gordon
Pugh, former all-American center,
and Moke Merriken, former captain and point at Hopkins ,has aided coaches Keech and Norris considerably
